comments:
This course examines the history, rationale and putative mechanism of action of
drugs used in the treatment of psychiatric disorders. Emphasis is placed on
neurobiological processes underlying psychopathology and pharmacological intervention.
Drugs currently in use as well as new drugs in development are covered. Strategies,
techniques, issues and challenges of clinical psychopharmacological research are
addressed and new approaches to drug discovery, including the use of pharmacogenomics
and proteomics to understand variability in drug response and identify new molecular
drug targets, are covered in depth. Specific drug classes considered include
antidepressants, anxiolytics, typical and atypical antipsychotics, narcotic analgesics,
sedative hypnotics, and antiepileptic medications. A contrasting theme throughout the
course is the use of drugs as probes to identify neural substrates of behavior.
The course was described as “organized” and “interesting.” Students generally
felt that they really learned a lot about pharmacological research that they would be “able
to use as a physician later on.” Students also felt that there was a lot of “great material”
covered and life advice provided during the course.
Professor Lexow received rave reviews from students. She was described as “one
of the best” professors at Penn. Students commented that Professor Lexow was able to
articulate her points and explain scientific concepts very well, had tons of life advice, and
“always kept the big picture in mind.”
Students recommended this course for students both in and out of the major.
Students did say that there was a lot of work, but that it’s worth it. Please note that this
review was based on less than 8 student comments.
